title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #637: Distinct Degrees in Induced Subgraphs**

**Question:** If G has no clique or independent set on ≫ log n vertices, must G contain an induced subgraph with ≫ √n distinct degrees?

**Answer: YES** (Bukh-Sudakov 2007)

**Strengthening:** JKLY (2020) improved to ≫ n^{2/3} distinct degrees without vertex count restriction.
mathContext: Ramsey graphs: ω(G), α(G) = O(log n). These are 'pseudo-random' graphs.

title: Vertex Degree
content:
**vertexDegree(G, v):**

The degree of vertex v in graph G - the number of neighbors of v.

```lean
noncomputable def vertexDegree (G : SimpleGraph V) (v : V) : ℕ :=
  (G.neighborFinset v).card
```

title: Distinct Degrees
content:
**distinctDegrees(G), numDistinctDegrees(G):**

The set and count of distinct degree values in graph G.

```lean
noncomputable def distinctDegrees (G : SimpleGraph V) : Finset ℕ :=
  Finset.image (vertexDegree G) Finset.univ
```

A regular graph has 1 distinct degree; most graphs have many.

title: Clique and Independence Numbers
content:
**cliqueNumber(G), independenceNumber(G):**

- ω(G) = maximum clique size
- α(G) = maximum independent set size = ω(Gᶜ)

These measure the 'most structured' parts of G.

title: Ramsey Graphs
content:
**IsRamseyGraph(G):**

G is a Ramsey graph if ω(G), α(G) = O(log n).

```lean
def IsRamseyGraph (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
  ∃ C > 0, HasSmallRamsey G C
```

**Key fact:** Random G(n, 1/2) is typically a Ramsey graph.

Ramsey graphs have no large 'regular' structure (cliques/independent sets).
mathContext: Named because ω(G), α(G) ≤ k implies n ≤ R(k+1, k+1).

title: Induced Subgraphs
content:
**inducedSubgraph(G, S):**

The induced subgraph on vertex set S - keeps only edges within S.

**inducedDistinctDegrees(G, S):** Count of distinct degrees in G[S].

**HasLargeInducedWithManyDegrees:** There exists S with |S| ≥ vertexBound and many distinct degrees.

title: Original Conjecture
content:
**OriginalConjecture (Erdős-Faudree-Sós):**

Ramsey graphs contain induced subgraphs on ≫ n vertices with ≫ √n distinct degrees.

```lean
def OriginalConjecture : Prop :=
  ∃ c₁ c₂ : ℝ, c₁ > 0 ∧ c₂ > 0 ∧ ...
    HasLargeInducedWithManyDegrees G ⌈c₁ * n⌉₊ ⌈c₂ * Real.sqrt n⌉₊
```

**Status: SOLVED** by Bukh-Sudakov (2007).

title: Bukh-Sudakov (2007)
content:
**bukh_sudakov:**

Proved the original Erdős-Faudree-Sós conjecture.

- Ramsey graphs have induced subgraph on ≫ n vertices
- With ≫ √n distinct degrees

This was the first proof of the conjecture.
mathContext: Uses regularity-type arguments and degree analysis.

title: Strengthened Conjecture
content:
**StrengthenedConjecture:**

Ramsey graphs have ≫ n^{2/3} distinct degrees (in the WHOLE graph, no vertex restriction).

```lean
def StrengthenedConjecture : Prop :=
  ∃ c : ℝ, c > 0 ∧ ...
    (numDistinctDegrees G : ℝ) ≥ c * n^(2/3 : ℝ)
```

Stronger than original: applies to G itself, not just induced subgraphs.

title: JKLY (2020)
content:
**jkly_strengthened:**

Jenssen-Keevash-Long-Yepremyan proved the strengthened conjecture.

- ≫ n^{2/3} distinct degrees in any Ramsey graph
- No restriction on vertex count of induced subgraph
- Exponent 2/3 believed optimal

Major improvement over Bukh-Sudakov's √n.
mathContext: Uses sophisticated probabilistic and algebraic methods.

title: Optimality
content:
**OptimalityConjecture:**

The exponent 2/3 is believed to be optimal.

There exist constructions showing you cannot do better than n^{2/3+o(1)}.

So JKLY's bound is essentially tight.

title: Regular Graphs
content:
**IsRegular, regular_one_degree:**

A k-regular graph has all degrees equal to k, so only 1 distinct degree.

**ramsey_not_too_regular:** Ramsey graphs cannot be too regular - they must have at least 2 distinct degrees for large n.

Ramsey property forces degree diversity.

title: Random Graphs
content:
**Random G(n, 1/2) properties:**

- Typically a Ramsey graph (ω, α ~ 2 log n)
- Has many distinct degrees (≈ n)
- Degrees concentrate around n/2

Random graphs are the prototypical Ramsey graphs.

title: Ramsey Connections
content:
**Ramsey number connections:**

- R(k,k) ≥ 2^{k/2} (probabilistic lower bound)
- If ω(G), α(G) ≤ k then n ≤ R(k+1, k+1)

The Ramsey graph condition constrains graph size.

title: Summary
content:
**Erdős Problem #637: SOLVED**

**Timeline:**
1. Erdős-Faudree-Sós: Conjecture (≫ √n degrees)
2. Bukh-Sudakov (2007): Proved original conjecture
3. JKLY (2020): Strengthened to ≫ n^{2/3} degrees

**Key insight:** Ramsey graphs (no large cliques/independent sets) must have high degree diversity.
